Situation1: A minor misunderstanding about weekend plans just arose.
Expectation2: Adhere to site protocols and work effectively as part of the team.
Situation2: The mandatory daily pre-work safety briefing is starting in two minutes.
Story: My phone buzzes in my pocket just as I’m pulling on my hard hat. It’s Mia—her message pops up, sharp and urgent: “Why didn’t you tell me you’re working Saturday? I thought we had plans.” My stomach twists. We’d talked about this, hadn’t we? Or maybe I forgot. She hates when I leave things hanging, expects me to talk things through, not just brush them off. I want to call her, to fix it before it grows into something bigger. But the foreman’s voice booms across the site, calling everyone to the safety briefing. It’s non-negotiable—if I’m late, I’ll get written up, maybe even sent home. The guys are already gathering, and I can’t be the one holding things up. My thumb hovers over the call button, heart pounding. I can’t be in two places at once, can’t be the perfect girlfriend and the reliable worker at the same time. The seconds tick by, and I feel the weight of both worlds pressing in, demanding I choose.
